Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2010 12:33PM AndreaS wrote: Carolyn, I had bought a mid-thigh to diaphram "spanx" before my surgery -- in my size.  After the surgery, the thought of pulling that thing on and off every time I went to the bathroom was daunting - it was sooo tight (even before surgery).  My doctor actually recommended high-waisted bike shorts, and I had some old tight exercise shorts from the 90's when waist bands were higher, so those worked OK, but weren't providing a lot of compression.. hmm.. I guess being 20 years old might have something to do with that. So I went to Macy's and there is a vast array of stretchy products - Flexee was the brand I bought.  It wasn't nearly as expensive as the spanx and a bit more giving.  I bought both another thigh-to-diaphram product and some underwear that looks like a high-waisted boy short with compression to just above the belly button.  I'm loving the boy shorts - and they aren't hideous. Good luck finding something.. it was almost too much choice. And good luck to Jac and Paula -- you'll do great, and the pre-surgery anxiety will be over soon!

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2010 10:06PM AndreaS wrote: Hi all, I've got a recliner question -- I have one, but it has the big right-side lever to do the reclining.  I'm going to be having a right-side mastectomy/DIEP.. and can't imagine being able to pull the lever.  I even went to the lazy-boy store and they all had the right-side lever.  I've seen a number of posts from people saying that was the only place they could sleep for a while - but I haven't seen any issues about the actual reclining action - do I just need to attach a bell to the recliner to have someone come and recline, or more importantly, un-recline me? Laurie - yeah, I think the care at UW is great, but I'm pretty damn frustrated with their scheduling system. Now that I have a date (and I could afford to wait a bit, although I think there was still some intervention by my BS), things seem to be fine.  Some times I think I should have looked into the New Orleans group.. but I'm also pretty happy to stay close to home.  I love your recent post.  How 'bout this freezing weather! Zogo - thanks, the photo is from New Zealand -- I've had 3 work trips there, one just after my first diagnosis, one just after radiation, one just after my second diagnosis.  I'm probably the only person who holds negative connotations with NZ.  I've got one more trip in February.. think I'll be able to enjoy it then???

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2010 08:04PM AndreaS wrote: My first pre-op appointment is on Friday, and as every day passes, I get more and more freaked out about the reality of this.  Did I really ask all the questions?  Am I really making the right choice (as if there were a lot of choices!)?  If I keep digging deeper into the medical journals will I find that article that says, "you don't really need to do this mastectomy, just take this wonder pill and you'll be fine"?  Along with my frantic search for the non-existent better option, I'm slowly getting things ready, making lists and more lists.. ugh, the distracted issue is terrible - one thing is all I can hold in my head without everything falling out - makes shopping challenging, but maybe I'll get a frequent visitor discount at Fred Meyer.  I resolved the recliner question by getting a reclining love seat - a bit of an extravagance at this point, but I can scooch from the reclined side to the un-reclined side to escape if I need to get up in the night.  I was really worried about getting stuck in the recliner.  We've got quite a list of December-ites.  I'm certainly thinking the best thoughts and wishes for you who are going through surgeries these first days of December.  Please let us know how you're doing when you can.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2010 09:43PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 04:22AM by AndreaS Last day at work today for a while.  Boy, did that make me feel like there's no turning back now - surgery is Monday.  I feel like I was planning for being gone a long time, while telling everyone I'd be back in after the new year (I wasn't specific about when after the new year). It's great to hear from all of you who have made it through your surgeries.  I hope it feels like a relief to be done with the anxiety - now the goal is clear: get healthy and mobile as smoothly and soon as possible.  I'm certainly ready to be done with the anxiety part and get my life back. Seems like there's a few of us from Seattle.. at least this is an OK time to not be out there and enjoying the outdoors.  I'll be OK with a stockpile of tea, netflix, trashy novels and my new recliner (although my boyfriend has definitely bonded with both the recliner and the new IPad I got for recovery). Have a good weekend to all of you. - Andrea

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 11:16AM AndreaS wrote: I'm back home!  Had my very long surgery on Monday (MX and DIEP) and finally got home yesterday.  Tried to use my IPad in the hospital, but I couldn't post, and to be honest, I had a hard time being interested in anything.  That's a heck of a surgery - 1 full day in surgery, 2 days in ICU, and then 2 more on the hospital ward.  I was so reay to be out of that blandly decorated hospital.  My house looks so colorful in comparison. Things look good (well, as good as a bunch of scars and bruises can get).  Trying to get excited about a little prune juice right now - that stuff is dreadful.  I think I can slow down on the Oxycodone pretty soon - my reward will be NO Prune Juice.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 01:14PM AndreaS wrote: Hi all, It's 2 weeks out now for me, and it seems like years have gone by since that Sunday two weeks ago when I was weepily steeling myself for surgery.  I got my drains out pretty quickly (two of them at 9 days, one at 11) and am really feeling pretty good - but moving awful slow.  My main problem is severe muscle tenseness in my back.  I can't stand up quite straight because of the abdominal incisions for the DIEP and so my back has been compensating (and having a hard time relaxing, even after I sit back down).  Went to a department store today to get some variety in abdominal compression - who would have known there is so much "slimming" wear out there?!  Not me.  I was thinking it would all look like grandma's girdle.  Now I feel quite fashionable.. Hope everyone had a good holiday and that the healing is going as well as it can.
